My worthy, reverend, trusty friend,</br>'Tis far from me to teaze ye;</br>At least what now I greeting send,</br>I hope, in sooth, will please ye.
'Tis not a poem with learning fraught;</br>To that I ne'er pretended:</br>Nor yet with Pope's fine touches wrought;</br>From that my time prevented.
There's nought of Byron, all sublime,</br>Or Moore so sweet bewitching:</br>To such a height I ne'er shall climb,</br>Although I feel an itching.
Nor yet of Scott's descriptive skill,</br>Or Campbell's lofty flight;</br>Theirs is for me too steep a hill,</br>Too far remov'd from sight.
Nor ought of Rogers can I boast,</br>Or Crabbe's minuter tale;</br>Which to admire I know not most,</br>To please they never fail.
There's nought of him whom all admire,</br>Who "Auburn's Village" sung;</br>Who, wand'ring, sweetly touch'd the lyre,</br>Whose harp with Edwin rung.
If like to any I would be,</br>And bards may have their choice;</br>Goldsmith!  it is no less than thee;</br>'Bove all I love thy voice.
There's none of Dryden's classic fire,</br>Or learned Gray profound;</br>Or he who sweetly did aspire,</br>Spenser, of fame renown'd.
Milton divine, and great Shakspeare,</br>With reverence I mention;</br>My name with theirs shall ne'er appear,</br>'Tis far from my intention.
If poetry, as one pretends,</br>Be all imagination,</br>Why, then, at once my bardship ends;</br>'Mong prose I take my station.
But if, as others strive to prove,</br>To common sense appealing,</br>That bards descriptive to remove,</br>And poets of tender feeling,
Would be, as though we strip the rose,</br>Of fragrance and of sweetness;</br>Then might we most our favourites close,</br>The very soul of greatness.
'Tis not imagination wakes</br>The patriot's breast to glow;</br>'Tis not imagination makes</br>The tear of pity flow.
'Tis words appealing to the heart,</br>That simply state of wrong;</br>That make the soul within us start,</br>And seek the injured throng.
'Tis poor misfortune's wailing voice</br>That draws the friendly hand;</br>That charity maketh to rejoice</br>Her bounty to expand.
That is the noblest verse of all,</br>Which aims to better man;</br>May never he from honour fall,</br>Who strives the best he can!
Thus I've beguil'd an hour of time</br>In courting of the Muses;</br>In writing rustic awkward rhyme,</br>The critic-world refuses.
I think at least no foes can rise,</br>So little I assume;</br>He ne'er can win who never tries,</br>The laurel, wreath, or plume.
Farewell!  farewell!  my worthy friend,</br>Awhile I bid adieu;</br>May happiness your paths attend,</br>With always hope in view!
You'll hear no more in verse from me,</br>If critics prove unkind;</br>My next in simple prose must be,</br>Unless I favour find.
And should my lucubrations meet</br>With wish'd-for inclination;</br>Why, then, again my friend I'll greet,</br>And seek his approbation.</br>
